name: Ava
comment info:
I notice that it describes types of people and if they can or can not vote in which states. I also notice that they tell us if that state is republican or democratic.
The information make me curious about the types of laws in some states, and why some types of people can't vote for some reason.
I believe that this info-graph is telling us the different types of people in the country and which states that they can and can not vote in.

name: W. Cameron
comment info: I wonder why the majority of adults do not vote when the impact of the election will effect everyones lives. I notice that that the new generation of voters are eager to make their voice heard by voting. I see that the majority of people who could not vote are republican and besides the groups of people who are convicted felons and those with no ID, Republicans could have a larger impact in the election if more registered to vote.

name: Claire
comment info: I think this is basically types of voters and if they could or could not vote...

name: John D
comment info: I notice that certain states are always on the "could vote" side, and others on the "could not vote" side. I wonder why this is; and if states could change their laws to allow more voters to participate.

replies.comment info: @John D, You birng up a very interesting question>  Which states always are on the "could not vote side"?  Do they have any similar characteristics?  What do you make of this?

comment info: i think it is intersting that there are so little student voters. i think that young kids should vote so that they excersice their right before they wish they didnt. one vote seems meaningless to kids and i think they need to realize their voice needs to be heard while they still can.

replies.comment info:

name: Sam
comment info: I notice that each person represents a state. What is the range of age for these voters? How old is the oldest and how young is the youngest?

name: Charlie
comment info: I notice that, in general, there are more Republican voters and Democratic voters, and most of the figures in the "Could Not Vote" section were mostly Republican. name: Megan
comment info: I notice there are more red firgurines that could not vote than blue. I also notice that each of the figurines is a specific state. replies.comment info: HI, @Megan.  You noticed about the figures and you think this may have to do with predictions.  Where do you see evidence about predictions?  You can look at the titles of the five types of voters as well as the original article itself.  The link is in the first paragraph of the release.  Now, what do you notice and wonder?

name: Caleb
comment info: Being a Marylander myself, I could not help but notice how, in each graph, Maryland is listed in the "could vote" section. I also noticed that the majority of the states in the "could not vote" section had a Republican majority. I wonder why so many Republican majority states are in the "could not vote" category. I infer that a lot of the Republican majority states have stricter voting laws, preventing people who lack an ID or are a convicted felon from voting.

replies.comment info: @Caleb.  You noticed.  You wondered.  And, you made a conjecture.  Does it hold true for other states that are different from Maryland?

name: Moderator Jen
comment info:
Thanks to all teachers and students who responded.  You can continue to post responses. Dig deeper into what the infographics shows. Please check back on Thursday afternoon, October 25 to see the Reveal with a link to the original New York Times article, some questions about the graphs, and one Stat Nugget.

The next graph will be released THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 1!  (There is no graph on Wednesday, October 31.)  You may respond before the live moderation on Wednesday, November 7, during the moderation, or after the moderation by going to the archives for the graph.  No surprise – the graph will have something to do with voting.   

Signing off – Sharon Hessney in Boston, Massachusetts, and Jennifer Mueller in St. Louis, Missouri, which in either state, if you are a Procrastinating Voter, you cannot vote.  (The reasons for being barred from voting may differ.)

name: Abbott
comment info:
I notice that high school students aren't even mentioned in this graph.  IF YOU ARE UNDER 18, YOU CAN'T VOTE IN ALL STATES.  There's no bigger barrier to voting than being deemed too young.

I wonder what would be different if citizens of ALL AGES could vote...  Would schools now filled with "voters" be better funded?  Would voter turnout be higher?  Why must you be 18 to vote?

My headline would be:  "Democrats & Republicans Agree:  We Don't Want Teens to Vote"

https://www.youthrights.org/issues/voting-age/top-ten-reasons-to-lower-t...

https://youtu.be/hSDxg-bDw1A

replies.name: M
replies.comment info: @Abbott   That is good point that isn't represented in the infographic.  Your questions "Would schools now filled with "voters" be better funded?  Would voter turnout be higher?  Why must you be 18 to vote?" are good questions.   Your headline is catchy for your idea!  Keep wondering and push for change!

Thank you @Abbott for sharing your recommendation on lowering the minimum voting age -- a barrier to voting.  The West Wing video clip and article give more insight.  I wonder which states would be most likely to support this reduction in barriers to voting.

name: Emerald Henry
comment info: Voting Time! We all see it coming and it’s almost here what this graph is portraying to this upcoming election, is that there is an astounding amount of Republicans over Democrats this year. Most likely due to the fact that we have a current Republican president. There are also many groups of people not voting for each category. replies.name: M
replies.comment info: @Emerald Henry   Thanks for your input and I love the plug to "get out and vote!"

name: Maggie
comment info:
I noticed that in the graphs for The Procrastinating Voter, The Convicted-Felon Voter, and The Working Parent Voter the amount that could not vote was greater than the amount that could vote.  I also noticed there were fewer Democrats in the could not vote section than Republicans.

Headline: To Vote or Not To Vote

replies.name: M

name: bARry
comment info: I noticed that were red states tended to have stricter voting rules and laws when compared with blue states. For instance in the No-ID voter 20 out of 33 of the red states require ID while 14 out of 17 blue states allowed people to vote. This is also apparent in the convicted felon voter where 13 out 18 blue states allowed convicted felons to regain voting rights. Where in red states only 8/33 states allowed voting rights to convicted felons. Through the data it appears that the red states are more selevtive in who they allow to vote.

replies.name: M
replies.comment info: @bARry   Those are some great observations!  I wonder why perhaps red states appear to have more selective laws?  Thank you for sharing what you noticed.

name: Joshua
comment info:
I noticed that in all the graphs the majority of the “individuals” were Republicans. However, there were a lot of republicans mostly in the “could not vote” section. I also noticed that out of all the categories the student category voted the most out of anyone.
I wonder, what is the variable that is preventing people from voting in the first place? Is it because of location, initiative, etc. 

Catchy headline: No voting in the land of the free

replies.comment info: @Joshua    Catchy Title! That makes me want to read the article.  The variable that you are wondering about could be the laws.  But is it State voting laws? Or Federal voting laws? I wonder which one/both are putting the restrictions.

name: Jett
comment info:
I notice that in all categories, the majority of people that cannot vote are in republican majority states. I also notice that the majority of procrastinating and convicted felon states could not vote compared to categories like eager students where 44 of the states no matter which party affiliation can vote likely because they are "eager" and thus they want to vote. One last thing I notice is that the majority of people that could vote from the No ID, Convicted felon or procrastinating voter categories were democratic states.
 I wonder first why is that the case? Why are the people that could vote in these three categories in particular from democratic states. But my main overall question is why are the republican majority states not voting? They like I said in all five categories have the majority of people not being able to vote from republican states. Right now in our political climate, they are the majority. Maybe some republicans feel obligated not to vote because of potential backlash from democratic peers or maybe they have limited access to vote. My catchy headline would be.

Republican majority but why don't they vote?

name: Chris
comment info:
I noticed that in all of the categories of voters the majority of states that could not vote were republicans majority states and the majority of states who could vote were majority democrat states.

replies.comment info: Hi, @Chris.  You wonder “Why Republicans aren't able to vote in more states because right now there is a Republican majority in the government?” I notice that the its both Republican and Democrats in these states who have barriers to voting, not just Republicans.  Using your headline, I ask  “Who is allowed to vote in your country?"

replies.name: D

name: Audrey
comment info:
In this graph, I noticed the following:
In regards to procrastinating voters, only 33% could vote. In comparison to convicted-felon voters, there is only an 8% increase in states that could vote. Moreover, between no ID and Working parent voters, only 54% and 47% could vote, respectively. While there is a majority of Democrats able to vote in the group of convicted-felon voters, the eager students that are able to vote have a Republican majority. 

I wonder why the Republican population has a greater amount of states not voting, especially considering that they are the majority party in the United States. Also, why do two groups have a summation of 51 while the others have a summation of 50? Do some groups consider TheDistrict of Columbia? 

I think this graph has a lot to do with the rise of hyperpartisanship, and how a majority of Americans feel reluctant to vote (as a result). I would title this graph: "Who is participating in our pluralist republic?" or "Apolitical strata limits the representation of the whole".

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Audrey.  I love BOTH of your headlines.  If I were the editor, I would have a hard time choosing which to use.
Many responders wrote about the number of non-voters.  But, I notice that this shows states in which there are non-voters.  Are non-voters and states with non-voters the same?  How are they different?
You notice that there is an 8% increase in states voting from Procrastinating Voters to Convicted-Felon Voters.  Talk to your classmates:  What is the difference between “8% increase” and “8% point increase?”
There has been another student responder who asked about the 51 state total.  Search for “51” in the responses and see what this students and I said.
Thank you for sharing your noticings and wonderings and those great headlines.

name: Moderator Sharon
comment info:
Teachers told us that they wanted to see the graphs sooner so there is more time to lesson plan.  Here is the revised schedule for “What’s Going On In This Graph?”.   

Thursday afternoons:  Release the graph for the following week.

Wednesday 9 am – 2 pm ET:  Live moderation

Thursday afternoon:  Reveal the article, additional questions, and the Stat Nuggets

Our next will be Wednesday, November 7.  It will be released on Thursday, November 1.
Please note that there will be no “What’s Going On In This Graph?” on Wednesday, October 31.

name: Moderator Sharon
comment info:
Welcome to Wednesday's moderation of  “What’s Going On in This Graph?” Today’s infographics focus on five barriers to voting and where they are in each of the 50 states plus the District of Columbia.  As we are six days from Election Day, think about what could prevent some who are eligible to vote.  Look at what affects voters in your state.  From 9 am – 2 pm E.T. today, give us your responses online to these three questions -- "What do you notice?",  "What do you Wonder?", and  "What's going on in this graph?"  Plus, share with us a catchy headline.
On Thursday afternoon, we’ll reveal the article that included these infographics and much more.

Learn different perspectives when you read what other students have to say about your response.  We look forward to reading your discoveries.

replies.name: B
replies.comment info: Election day i forgot all about it but what could prevent them from voting , thats crazy@Moderator Sharon

name: Liana
comment info:
I notice that most of Eager Students could vote while the majority of Procrastinating Voters and Convicted-Felon Voters could not.
I wonder why most Republican states could not vote while most Democratic states could.
My headline would be "Who is Actually Voting?"

replies.comment info: HI, @Liana.  You noticed that “most of Eager Students could vote while the majority of Procrastinating Voters and Convicted-Felon Voters could not. “I wonder what you mean by “most. “Most people, or most states?

replies.name: a
replies.comment info: @Liana I feel as if it was that way because the students were more opened to voting the convicts.

name: Dakota
comment info:
I noticed that the "No-ID Voters"  that could not vote were almost all in Republican states and those who could vote were primarily from Democrat states. I also noticed that most people who could not vote in each state were from states with a Republican majority in the House of Representatives.

I wonder why states with a Republican majority in the House of Representatives are mostly those who have populations that are ineligible or are not able to vote.

A catchy headline can be "Why aren't Republicans voting?"

replies.comment info:
Welcome, @Dakota.  You focused on No ID Voters, but you also combined all of the other types of barriers to voting to generalize for these five barriers.  I wonder if there are other barriers?
This infographic shows barriers by state.  What about by population?  What do you think about proportion of  the U. S. population that is affected by a specific barrier?  Or any barrier?  There are 96 barriers from Republican majority and 25 barriers from Democratic majority in their state House of Representatives.  That’s 79% and 21% of the barriers from Republican and from Democratic states, respectively.  Just looking at which states have barriers, do these percentages hold for the total population?  If not, how would they be different?

name: Zoe
comment info:
I notice that a majority of the states that could vote for the procrastinating voter, the procrastinating voter, and the convicted-felon voter were Democratic. Meanwhile, all the states that could not vote for each section were Republican. Also majority of the eager student voters who could vote were from Republican states. It seems that the more educated states (working parent and eager student voters) were Republican states.
I wonder why for each section, the two numbers add up to 51 states instead of 50. Because there are 50 states in the U.S., so I don't understand why there are 51 states accounted for in this graph. Was D.C. counted as a state?
A catchy headline for this graph could be "Republican states vote less"

replies.comment info: @Zoe.  You make quite a few noticings.  I would add I notice that I make:  For each of the 5 barriers, there are 33 Republican state majorities and 18 Democratic state majorities.  How could this noticing be incorporated into your wonderings?  Please share with us your ideas.

name: Jesse
comment info:
I notice that the majority of people in each state that could not vote are Republican for every graph. Also, I notice that every state categorized as Eager Student Voters who could not vote were Republican as well.
I wonder if the majority of people who could not vote are Republicans due to the possibility of being labeled racist and misogynist for voting for Trump which would lead to not participating in the election.
A catchy headline could be "Republicans hide from the heat".

replies.comment info: &Jesse, your headline is very, very catchy!  But, I noticed the explanation of the red and blue little people.  This explanation differentiates between the two.  Maybe you will notice and wonder other items after honing in on the difference.  Let us know what you thing.

name: Judy Chicago
comment info: I notice that a lot of progress has been made in allowing Eager Students to vote. Among the 51 Voting Units (50 states plus Washington, DC), only seven states or 14% appear to prevent Eager Students from voting. That said, the underlying article indicates that some among the 86% of units that do permit students to vote, such as Wisconsin, impose restrictions that make it difficult to succeed in doing so. My headline might be: "Student Voting in Elections is Not as Simple as It Seems"

replies.comment info: Thank you @Judy Chicago for noticing about Eager Students.  I wonder what makes them “Eager.”  You notice that 14% of the states don’t let Eager Students vote.  I wonder if this is 14% of the country’s voters?  What do you think?  Seeing that your headline is “Student Voting in Elections is Not as Simple as It Seem,” I wonder what makes it not so simple.
